data.title: Kyushu Rail Pass

data.text:
JR Kyushu Rail Pass

The JR Kyushu Rail Pass is a must-have for travellers aiming to explore the wonders of Kyushu. The pass, which comes in four varieties, offers unlimited rides on JR Kyushu trains, including the Kyushu and Nishi Kyushu Shinkansen.

If you’re ready to explore Kyushu, let’s look at the JR Kyushu rail pass in detail and how it can help you in your journey.

Eligibility

The JR Kyushu Rail Pass is primarily designed for tourists visiting Japan from abroad. Specifically, you must own a foreign passport and enter Japan on a “Temporary Visitor” status. This will be designated by an entry stamp or seal on your passport. Japanese citizens and residents are not eligible for this pass.

Price

The price of the JR Kyushu Rail Pass varies depending on the type and duration of the pass. There are four different types available:

All Kyushu

Northern Kyushu

Southern Kyushu

Fukuoka-wide

Here are their prices; please note that JR is increasing the cost of passes on the 1st of October, 2023:

Prices starting the 1st of October 2023

Pass type Duration Adult Price Child (6-11) Price All Kyushu 3 Days 20,000 yen 10,000 yen 5 Days 22,500 yen 11,250 yen 7 Days 25,000 yen 12,500 yen Northern Kyushu 3 Days 12,000 yen 6,000 yen 5 Days 15,000 yen 7,500 yen Southern Kyushu 3 Days 10,000 yen 5,000 yen Fukuoka-wide 2 Days 3,060 yen 1,530 yen

How to Purchase the Pass or Exchange Your Voucher

You have four ways of buying the pass:

JR Kyushu Online Booking website

Local travel agency outside of Japan

In-flight shopping (if offered, depending on the airline)

Designated JR Kyushu Station ticket offices:

Hakata Station (7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu, Northern Kyushu, and Fukuoka-wide passes only

Kokura Station (7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu, Northern Kyushu, and Fukuoka-wide passes only

Mojiko Station (7:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu, Northern Kyushu, and Fukuoka-wide passes only

Saga Station (7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu and Northern Kyushu passes only

Nagasaki Station (7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu and Northern Kyushu passes only

Sasebo Station (7:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu and Northern Kyushu passes only

Beppu Station (7:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu and Northern Kyushu passes only

Oita Station (7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu, Northern Kyushu, and Southern Kyushu passes only

Kumamoto Station (7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu, Northern Kyushu, and Southern Kyushu passes only

Kagoshima-chuo Station (7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu and Southern Kyushu passes only

Miyazaki Station (7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu and Southern Kyushu passes only

Miyazaki Airport JR Ticket Office (10 a.m. to 12:10 p.m., 12:50 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. daily) – All Kyushu and Southern Kyushu passes only

You can purchase your pass up to one month before your desired travel date. Buying the pass from outside Japan means you’ll receive a voucher called MCO (Miscellaneous Charges Order). You can exchange this voucher to get your pass from any of the stations listed above. This voucher is valid for up to 90 days from the date of purchase.

To exchange your voucher for the pass, bring your MCO, the payment method used to purchase the pass, and your passport to the ticket office. You must pay for a new pass if you do not have the original debit or credit card used to purchase the voucher.

Unused passes bought from the JR Kyushu Rail Pass Online Booking website or a ticket office are eligible for a refund one day before the start date of the pass. You will get your money back, minus a 10 per cent handling charge.

Please note that JR Kyushu cannot issue refunds for passes purchased from an overseas travel agent. You’ll have to contact your travel agent for assistance.

How to Use the Pass

The JR Kyushu Pass is issued as a ticket that can be used to access automatic ticket gates. Simply insert the ticket and collect it as you pass the gate.

This pass, except for the Fukuoka-wide pass, also entitles you to free seat reservations. All Kyushu pass holders can make as many seat reservations as they wish, while Northern and Southern Kyushu pass holders can make up to six free seat reservations. Those who exceed this limit will be required to purchase a separate express ticket. You can do this at any JR ticket office (Midori-no-madoguchi) or at a JR Kyushu reserved-seat ticket vending machine.

You can also reserve seats through the JR Kyushu Rail Pass Online Booking website. However, there is a charge of 1,000 yen (500 yen for children) per reservation. Seat reservations made online do not count toward your seat reservation limits.

Validity and Exclusions

The JR Kyushu Rail Pass is valid for unlimited rides on JR Kyushu trains, depending on your pass type. Here are the trains covered for each pass:

All Kyushu Pass

Any local JR train

Any limited express train

Kyushu Shinkansen between Hakata to Kagoshima-chuo

Nishi Kyushu Shinkansen between Takeo-onsen and Nagasaki

Northern Kyushu Pass (covering Nagasaki, Kumamoto, Oita, and areas north of them)

Any local JR train in the coverage area

Any limited express train in the coverage area

Kyushu Shinkansen between Hakata to Kagoshima-chuo

Nishi Kyushu Shinkansen between Takeo-onsen and Nagasaki

Southern Kyushu Pass (covering Kumamoto, Oita, and areas south of them

Any local JR train in the coverage area

Any limited express train in the coverage area

Kyushu Shinkansen between Kumamoto to Kagoshima-chuo

Fukuoka-wide Pass

Limited express trains in Fukuoka (non-reserved seats only)

Rapid/local trains in Fukuoka

The pass’s validity starts from the activation date and lasts three, five, or seven consecutive days. The day you activate the pass counts as day 1, regardless of the time. Day 2 starts at 12:01 a.m. the next day, and the pass expires at midnight on days 3, 5, or 7.

The JR Kyushu Rail Pass is not valid on the Shinkansen between Hakata and Kokura, as it is part of JR West’s Sanyo Shinkansen. You must pay additional fees if you wish to travel in Green Cars.

You cannot use any type of JR Kyushu Rail Pass on the following:

JR Kyushu buses

B&S Miyazaki buses

Cruise Train Seven Stars

Aru Ressha (Sweet Train)

Welcome to Kyushu, Japan’s captivating third-largest island nestled in the southwestern part of the country. With its modern cities, breathtaking natural beauty, and rich historical heritage, Kyushu offers an unforgettable adventure for every type of traveler. From the awe-inspiring Mount Aso, one of the world’s largest active volcanoes, to the healing waters of Beppu and Yufuin’s renowned hot springs, this remarkable region is brimming with wonders waiting to be explored.

1. Discovering the Natural Marvels

1.1 Mount Aso: A Volcanic Wonder

Prepare to be enthralled by the majestic presence of Mount Aso, a colossal active volcano that dominates the Kyushu landscape. Towering above the surrounding valleys, Mount Aso offers a truly awe-inspiring experience. Its vast caldera, one of the largest in the world, is a testament to the region’s volcanic activity. Embark on a thrilling hike to the summit and marvel at the panoramic views of the sprawling landscape below. As you navigate the rugged terrain, you’ll feel a sense of wonder at the raw power of nature.

1.2 Beppu and Yufuin: Soothing Hot Springs

When it comes to relaxation and rejuvenation, Beppu and Yufuin are unparalleled. These charming towns are renowned for their therapeutic hot springs, known as onsen in Japanese. Immerse yourself in the warm, mineral-rich waters and feel your worries melt away. Beppu, often referred to as the “Onsen Capital of Japan,” boasts a wide array of hot spring baths, each with its unique healing properties. Yufuin, on the other hand, offers a more tranquil setting, surrounded by picturesque mountains and quaint cafes. Indulge in a peaceful soak and let the healing waters revitalize your body and soul.

2. Immerse Yourself in History and Culture

2.1 Arita and Imari: The Birthplace of Japanese Ceramics

Kyushu’s rich cultural heritage is deeply intertwined with the art of ceramics. Journey to the towns of Arita and Imari, renowned for their exquisite porcelain production. With a history dating back centuries, these towns have cultivated a tradition of craftsmanship that is truly unparalleled. Explore the workshops and kilns, witnessing firsthand the meticulous techniques employed by skilled artisans. Admire the delicate beauty of the ceramics and perhaps even take home a unique piece as a memento of your journey through Kyushu.

2.2 Kumamoto: A Glimpse into Feudal Japan

Step back in time as you explore the historic town of Kumamoto, a symbol of Japan’s feudal past. Wander through the meticulously preserved samurai residences and immerse yourself in the rich history that permeates the streets. Marvel at the grandeur of Kumamoto Castle, a magnificent fortress dating back to the 17th century. As you walk through its imposing gates, you’ll be transported to a bygone era, where warriors roamed and legends were born. Uncover the stories that shaped this town and gain a deeper understanding of Japan’s captivating heritage.

3. Unveiling Kyushu’s Hidden Gems

3.1 Yakushima Island: Nature’s Paradise

In the southernmost part of Kyushu lies Yakushima Island, a true paradise for nature enthusiasts. This UNESCO World Heritage site boasts lush forests, pristine beaches, and awe-inspiring waterfalls. Embark on a trek through the ancient cedar forests, where towering trees create a canopy of green. The enchanting atmosphere is so captivating that it served as the inspiration for the magical world of Studio Ghibli’s film, “Princess Mononoke.” Lose yourself in the tranquillity of this untouched wilderness and let its beauty leave an indelible mark on your soul.

3.2 Nagasaki: A City of Resilience and Remembrance

Nestled on the western coast of Kyushu, Nagasaki is a city that tells a story of resilience and remembrance. It is here that the devastating atomic bomb was dropped during World War II, forever altering the course of history. Visit the Nagasaki Peace Park and Atomic Bomb Museum to pay tribute to the lives lost and to gain a deeper understanding of the consequences of war. Despite its painful past, Nagasaki has risen from the ashes, becoming a vibrant city that embraces peace and promotes cultural diversity. Explore its charming streets, bustling markets, and vibrant festivals, and witness the indomitable spirit of its people.

4. Embrace the Spirit of Kyushu

Kyushu is more than just a destination; it’s an experience that will ignite your sense of adventure and leave you with unforgettable memories. Whether you’re marveling at the raw power of Mount Aso, indulging in the healing waters of Beppu and Yufuin, immersing yourself in the history of Kumamoto, exploring the hidden gems of Yakushima Island, or paying homage to Nagasaki’s resilient spirit, Kyushu promises to captivate your heart and soul. So, pack your bags, embark on a journey of a lifetime, and let Kyushu’s wonders envelop you in a world of beauty and enchantment.
